tree.description: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005

root.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
root.pub-comments: This tree is an amalgamation of subtrees of the pidgin and creole trees provided in Ethnologue. It has been broken into regions for ease of searching.
root.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Further removed from Ndyuka than Aluku and Paramaccan.
child.geography: Suriname, north central, along the Coppename River, upstream from Carib villages in Kaimanstan and Witagron.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Kwinti is further removed from Aukan than are Aluku and Paramaccan.
child.geography: Suriname, eastern along the Marowijne and Tapanahony rivers, northeastern along the Cottica River. Aluku are along the French Guiana border. Also spoken in French Guiana.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Similar to Ndyuka, but there are cultural differences. Also has many similarities to Krio of Sierra Leone.
child.geography: Suriname, mainly in Paramaribo and along the coast. Also spoken in Aruba, Netherlands, Netherlands Antilles.
child.alt-names: Sranan Tongo, Taki-Taki, Surinaams, Surinamese, Suriname Creole English
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: There is reported to be a 'deep Creole'. Very close to Belize Creole English.
child.geography: Columbia, San Andrés and Providencia Islands.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: It may be intelligible with other English-based creoles of the Caribbean. Closest to creoles of Saint Vincent and Tobago. Rupununi may be a separate language. Speakers of Rupununi, Berbice Creole Dutch, and Skepi Creole Dutch claim they are not inherently intelligible with each other.
child.geography: Guyana, Georgetown, coast, and Rupununi River area. There may be some in French Guiana. Also spoken in Suriname, USA.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Ian Hancock classifies it as Portuguese based rather than English based. Linguistic influences from Kongo (Hancock 1988). 20% or more of the lexicon has an African component.
child.geography: Suriname, central, along Saramacca and upper Suriname rivers. Refugees are in Paramaribo. Also spoken in French Guiana.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.geography: Brazil, throughout State of Amapá, concentrated around the capital, Macapá.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.geography: Brazil, Amapá, on French Guiana border.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Bantu lexicon in Portuguese morphological and syntactic framework. A similar creole has been recently discovered in Minas Gerais.
child.geography: Brazil, Cafundo, 150 miles from São Paulo.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Speakers said it was not inherently intelligible with Berbice or Rupununi. Lexical similarity 52% with Berbice.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.geography: Formerly in Leeward Islands, Puerto Rico, St. John, St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Speakers claim it is not inherently intelligible with Skepi or Rupununi. About 30% of the basic lexicon and most of the productive morphology is from Eastern Ijo in Nigeria; most of the rest of the lexicon is from Dutch, 10% loans from Arawak and Guyanese Creole English.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: South American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Entirely unintelligible to Spanish speakers. Linguistic influences from Kongo in Democratic Republic of the Congo (I. Hancock 1987).
child.geography: Colombia, village of San Basilio de Palenque southeast of Cartagena, and 2 neighborhoods in Barranquilla.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
